text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Cases are stories.

It's real people
in real situations.

They take you from an issue
to what the possibilities are,

to what the outcome might
be, and then next steps.
So I like that narrative.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Three cases
illustrate for me what

the power of the right
story on the part of leaders

is, as leaders are
trying to get people

to think differently,
think outside the building,

meaning outside our current
structures and frameworks.

And when a new CEO comes
in, the first thing

is how to get people out
of those habitual mindsets

to thinking differently
about action possibilities.

So in "The Weather
Company," a new CEO came in

and he created his 4S
framework-- science, service,
stories, safety.

And each of those
embedded a core value

of the company, something
that the people in the company

could see appealing to
them but also uniting them

as he made acquisitions
and as he had to figure out

how a TV channel would work with
the increasing digital world.

So I like the fact that
other companies are also

going through the same thing,
whether it's a turnaround
or not.

When Monique Leroux
became CEO of Desjardins,

a large bank in Canada, but a
cooperative, which meant she
had to be elected.

And so she needed
a story to tell

about what she would do as CEO
and how it would benefit people
in the company.

And it was the combination of
her personal persuasiveness

and the story she told that not
only got her elected when she

was the one person out
of seven who was female

and was not the
favored candidate,

but the power of her story
inspired and enlisted

people in the change
she wanted to see.

And her story told them why
it would be good for them

and why the future could
rely on the roots of the past

but also take them to a
different level of performance.

And Haier, a Chinese global
giant appliance company.

Haier also has benefited from
the power of the founding

story, but also
the CEO's ability

to create theories
and frameworks

to guide a very new and
different kind of action.

It started out as a little
communist neighborhood

appliance factory, but the
CEO had enormous vision

and then to create a
theory about why it all
came back to the customer.

He wanted zero
distance to customers.

And that led him to a
story about how everybody

could be an entrepreneur
and everybody

could build a business
off of the appliance
platform of Haier.
They could create an ecosystem.

So it's both a
dramatic new management

model, a Chinese giant, and also
leadership as a powerful story.

I learn from all of
these cases and I learn
from what the students say.

The students assess
these stories,

the students say what
story they would tell.

So the case method, my studies
of leadership, what leaders do,
they're all in perfect harmony.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
